Article Title: No interim relief for Bajrang as court seeks Nada's response
Article Text: The Delhi high court has refused to grant interim relief to wrestler Bajrang Punia in the matter involving his provisional suspension by National Anti-Doping Agency (Nada). The court, however, has sought response from Nada regarding Bajrang's petition challenging the suspension for his refusal to provide urine sample for dope testing during the wrestling selection trials in Sonepat on March 10.Nada's counsel informed the court that a disciplinary panel has been formed and a hearing into the matter will be held.
Article Summary: The Delhi high court refused to grant interim relief to wrestler Bajrang Punia in the matter involving his provisional suspension by National Anti-Doping Agency (Nada) The court, however, has sought response from Nada regarding the petition challenging the suspension for his refusal to provide urine sample for dope testing.

Article Title: India plans to position itself as global green hydrogen hub: PM Modi
Article Text: NEW DELHI: PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday announced his plan to make India a global hub for green hydrogen (GH2), building upon the country's achievement of becoming the first among G20 economies to meet green energy commitment made at 2021 Paris UN climate change conference (CO) nine years ahead of the 2030 target."We are not resting on these achievements and the nation remains focused on strengthening existing solutions while also looking at new and innovative areas.This is where green hydrogen comes into the picture... We aim to position India as a global hub for production, utilisation, and export of green hydrogen. National Green Hydrogen Mission ( NGHM ) launched in 2023 is a critical step toward realising this ambition. It will drive innovation, build infrastructure, stimulate industry growth, and attract investment in the sector," he said in his inaugural speech delivered virtually at the 2nd International Green Hydrogen Conference.Pointing out India's installed non-fossil fuel capacity "increased 300% and solar energy capacity received a boost of 3,000%" in the past 10 years, Modi said GH2 can help decarbonise heavy industries and long-haul transport. GH2 is produced through electrolysis using renewable power as opposed to extraction from natural gas, which is termed 'grey'.The rapid expansion in renewables capacity since 2014, when Modi first became PM, provides the foundation for NGHM with a target of achieving five million tonnes of annual GH2 production capacity by 2030. Govt is offering a production-linked incentive of Rs 13,050 crore for GH2 production and Rs 4,440 crore for electrolyser manufacturing.Renewable energy minister Pralhad Joshi said NGHM has the potential to attract Rs 8 lakh crore in investments, generate six lakh jobs and lead to savings of Rs 1 lakh crore by reducing natural gas and ammonia imports. Oil minister Hardeep Puri said NGHM will reduce 15 million tonnes of CO2 emissions annually.
Article Summary: PM Narendra Modi announced his plan to make India a global hub for green hydrogen. National Green Hydrogen Mission ( NGHM) launched in 2023. GH2 is produced through electrolysis using renewable power as opposed to extraction from natural gas, which is termed 'grey'

Article Title: Shraddananda to SC: Am I worse than Rajiv killers?
Article Text: Sentenced to spend entire natural life in prison for murdering his wife, who was the granddaughter of ex-Diwan of Mysore, Swamy Shraddananda on Wednesday requested the SC to reconsider his sentence by asking - "Am I a worse offender than killers of Rajiv Gandhi and 15 others, who were released after 27 years in prison?"Shraddananda aka Murli Manohar was sentenced to entire life in prison by the SC in July 2008 after commuting the death sentence awarded to him concurrently by the trial court and the HC for murdering Shakereh in 1991.He had buried her body in the backyard of their house.
Article Summary: Shraddananda aka Murli Manohar was sentenced to entire life in prison by the SC in July 2008 after commuting the death sentence awarded to him concurrently by the trial court and the HC. He had buried her body in the backyard of their house.

Article Title: HC grants bail to 8-months pregnant life convict
Article Text: A division bench of Allahabad high court , comprising Justices Ashwani Kumar Mishra and Prashant Kumar , directed additional district and sessions judge in Pilibhit to release convict Geeta Devi on bail. Devi, sentenced to life imprisonment on Feb 22 this year for the murder of her 19-year-old nephew, Aman, on Aug 27, 2019.The HC, in its order dated Sept 9, noted that Geeta Devi is "presently 8 months pregnant." The order was issued following an appeal filed on medical grounds for suspension of her sentence and granting of bail.
Article Summary: Allahabad high court orders release of convict Geeta Devi on bail. Devi, sentenced to life imprisonment on Feb 22 this year for the murder of her 19-year-old nephew, Aman, on Aug 27, 2019. HC, in its order dated Sept 9, noted that Geeta Devi is "presently 8 months pregnant"

Article Title: Kejriwal wife on AAP star campaigner list
Article Text: As AAP gears up to fight all 90 seats in Haryana, it released a list of 40 star campaigners with party chief Arvind Kejriwal at the top and wife Sunita at the number two spot, overtaking former Delhi deputy CM Manish Sisodia who figures at number three followed by Punjab CM Bhagwant Mann.Sunita had figured at number two in the list of star campaigners even during the Lok Sabha polls but at that time, Sisodia was in jail.On Sunita's continued presence at number two in the list, AAP sources said there was no attempt to diminish Sisodia's status.
Article Summary: AAP releases a list of 40 star campaigners with party chief Arvind Kejriwal at the top and wife Sunita at the number two spot. Sunita had figured at number two in the list of star campaigners even during the Lok Sabha polls but at that time, Sisodia was in jail.

Article Title: SC sets aside HC order, asks CBI to probe Chhattisgarh ADJ wife's death
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court has ordered CBI to investigate the 2016 death by suicide of the wife of an additional district and sessions judge as her kin alleged that Chhattisgarh Police , under the influence of the judicial officer, closed the case despite several ante-mortem injuries found on her body.The kin of the deceased, who was an assistant district prosecution officer at Dantewada at the time of her marriage to the judicial officer in Feb 2014, alleged that she was killed in May 2016 and the police refused to even register an FIR by terming the incident as death by suicide.Their repeated complaints to the police brass went unheeded.When her relatives approached the HC for a CBI probe, the court kept the petition pending for seven years before dismissing it. The HC said they could move the magisterial court under the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) seeking registration of FIR. The mother and brother of the deceased moved SC against the HC order.Setting aside the HC order, the SC directed CBI to expeditiously carry out the probe and submit a report to the SC.
Article Summary: The Supreme Court has ordered CBI to investigate the 2016 death by suicide of the wife of an additional district and sessions judge. Her kin alleged that Chhattisgarh Police, under the influence of the judicial officer, closed the case despite several ante-mortem injuries found on her body.

Article Title: College acts against doctors, students over misconduct
Article Text: KOLKATA: North Bengal Medical College cracked the whip on four junior doctors and five students after getting complaints of intimidation and irregularities, like manipulating exams and collecting money from other students and junior doctors.The house staffship of three doctors has been terminated, while the internship of another has been terminated.
Article Summary: North Bengal Medical College cracked the whip on four junior doctors and five students. The house staffship of three doctors has been terminated, while the internship of another has also been terminated. The college received complaints of intimidation and irregularities, like manipulating exams and collecting money from students.
